stream_context.summary: Kaze implements and tunes a paper-airplane traversal mechanic for an unnamed multi-biome course (Course 14), aiming for a “swoop” flight path that lands on/into a pyramid as a way to reach the top. He finishes the paper-airplane feature and its target mission, adds/validates NPC interactions (a large cardboard-cutout Toad that dispenses a star), and begins/repairs the rubber-band/slingshot animation pipeline in Blender/Fast64. He also showcases demo readiness and N64-specific rendering/performance fixes (anti-aliasing toggle, coverage/alpha artifact removal, remaining Z-order issues) and discusses tooling limits (mipmaps/midmap levels) and performance constraints (RSP bottleneck, F3DEX3).
stream_context.significance_reason: Kaze declares the paper airplane finished (completing the associated target mission) and states the demo is done with N64 bugs fixed, then moves on to the next major interaction (rubber-band slingshot animation).

findings.summary: Kaze completes the paper-airplane mechanic and considers the associated “target mission” finished: the plane flight now works reliably enough to ship in the demo, with failure states if launched with too little speed.

The paper airplane is intended as a traversal tool to reach the pyramid: on contact with the pyramid, the plane’s movement should stop, effectively making it a ride/step-up mechanic rather than free-flight.

Paper-airplane flight is implemented as a custom physics approximation (not spline-driven), tuned through pitch/velocity coupling, friction, gravity-like terms, and clamps to avoid runaway rotation; Kaze explicitly prioritizes a physical basis even if the equations are “fudged.”
A key bug during tuning was caused by using an uninitialized/random stack value (he identifies this as “the issue” once found), which destabilized behavior until corrected.

Kaze rejects making the plane simply fly straight: he wants a characteristic “swoop swoop” wave-like flight path that looks like a paper airplane, while still being controllable enough to land at a specific target area near the pyramid.
He uses Mario 64’s gravity constant as a realism anchor: a velocity factor of 4 ‘makes sense’ because gravity is 4 in Mario 64, and that setting produced more believable motion.
He finishes “paper targets” off-stream: targets can now be broken by colliding with Mario’s face; they still need a dedicated animation, but the interaction works.

Course 14 is described as having multiple distinct biomes/visual zones (desert/pyramid area, mountains with a Styrofoam look, a castle area, and grasslands). The course name is not final; ‘Handmade Heights’ is floated as a candidate.

Kaze states the demo is done and he ‘fixed all the N64 bugs’ he’s aware of, but notes he still needs more console testing. He plans a video of himself playing through the demo for verification/documentation.

On real N64, he fixed anti-aliasing options: with AA disabled he reports ‘almost 50 FPS’ in a shown area. He also fixed a visible line/artifact caused by a coverage*alpha issue; however, at least two Z-ordering issues remain visible in the background.

He clarifies that texture flicker is a mipmapping/midmap-level problem, not solved by anti-aliasing. Fast64 currently supports only two midmap levels; using more would require hand-writing display lists and reinserting them after each export, which he deems too costly for iteration.
He notes some visual ‘offset textures’ are an emulator-only Glide bug and look correct on N64, implying the team must validate visuals on hardware rather than trust emulation artifacts.

He mentions engine/performance evolution: F3DEX3 is now in the game and provides performance improvements (triangle fences/strips, occlusion plane), but he’s now RSP-bottlenecked, shifting optimization priorities.

Zeina appears briefly on stream; Kaze shows her the paper airplane and notes remaining work includes the slingshot that actually flings Mario. Kaze also states he’s not the game’s animator, aiming only to create a workable base for animation tasks.

Rubber-band/slingshot animation work in Blender/Fast64: Kaze initially gets broken behavior because the ‘first animation frame wasn’t exporting’ due to a “smart animation range” feature that trims frames before the first keyed frame. Adding a keyframe before frame 1 fixes the export and restores intended motion.

biobak.summary: Biobak appears in chat; Kaze greets him while dealing with plane-physics tuning and chat frustration, implying Biobak is present during implementation/tuning sessions even when not actively directing decisions in this transcript.

zeina.summary: Zeina checks in during the stream; Kaze demonstrates the finished paper-airplane mechanic and highlights the next dependency: implementing the slingshot/rubber-band to actually launch Mario, tying level interactions to animation/rigging work.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I thought what made you insane when you romhack is the romhacking itself. But no, it’s Twitch chat like watching you romhack.
memorable_quotes.context: Kaze vents about the psychological strain of live development and constant viewer interrogation while he’s building an unfinished system.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I think the bar for 3D platformers is so incredibly low that making a 3D platformer is easy at this point.
memorable_quotes.context: Design/philosophy statement about why a ‘pure fun platformer’ can stand out today—relevant to why he believes this project will resonate.

key_stories.title: Building a paper-airplane traversal system by “fudging” physics until it feels right
key_stories.summary: Kaze tries to create a paper-airplane ride that naturally rises, loses speed, tips forward, and regains speed in a repeating swoop—while still landing at a precise pyramid target. The system repeatedly becomes unstable (spins/backflips), too stable (never tips), or stalls at zero velocity, forcing iterative tuning.
key_stories.challenge: Designing a motion path that feels like a paper airplane (wave-like swoops) but behaves reliably as a platforming mechanic to reach the pyramid, within Mario 64’s engine constraints.
key_stories.process: He iterates on equations coupling face-angle pitch and forward velocity, adds friction and clamp limits, uses gravity-like constants for plausibility, and debugs a destabilizing uninitialized stack value. He explicitly rejects replacing the motion with a spline because he wants a physically grounded base.
key_stories.outcome: He declares the paper airplane ‘done,’ completing the target mission and moving on to the next interaction (rubber-band/slingshot).
key_stories.key_quote: At this point, I’m just fucking with the numbers until I get something decent.

key_stories.title: Demo readiness and real-N64 rendering/performance fixes
key_stories.summary: Kaze shows the demo running on N64 and highlights fixes that make the build more presentable: anti-aliasing toggles, improved performance, and removal of a coverage/alpha artifact line. He also identifies remaining Z-ordering issues and reiterates the need for hardware validation because emulators can mislead (Glide bugs).
key_stories.challenge: Getting a decomp-based ROM hack to look correct and run smoothly on original N64 hardware, while tooling (Fast64) limits midmap/mipmap workflows.
key_stories.process: He fixes AA option handling, investigates coverage/alpha artifacts, checks HUD appearance on N64, and evaluates performance gains (near-60 in some areas, ~50 with AA off). He documents that more midmap levels would require hand-authored display lists, slowing iteration too much.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze says the demo is done and N64 bugs are fixed to his knowledge, but he still plans full console playthrough testing.
key_stories.key_quote: The demo is all done, by the way. I fixed all the N64 bugs.

key_stories.title: Fast64 ‘smart animation range’ silently breaking the slingshot animation
key_stories.summary: While animating the rubber-band/slingshot, Kaze finds the motion doesn’t match the measured seven-frame timing he expects. He discovers Fast64 trimmed the first frame because the export range starts at the first keyed frame, effectively deleting needed initial pose data.
key_stories.challenge: Pipeline/tooling issue: animation export changes timing/poses, causing broken in-game behavior despite correct Blender setup.
key_stories.process: He diagnoses the missing first frame, suspects Fast64 behavior, and fixes it by ensuring a keyframe exists before frame 1 so the export doesn’t trim the start state.
key_stories.outcome: The rubber-band animation becomes smooth and correct-looking, giving a usable base for future polish (sound effects, final timing).
key_stories.key_quote: The first animation frame wasn’t exporting because there’s a smart animation range feature.

open_questions.topic: Paper airplane landing/interaction rules at the pyramid
open_questions.context: Kaze wants the plane to stop once it touches the pyramid and to land slightly higher, but he is still tuning values and the exact stop condition/feel.
questions: What exact collision condition should ‘stop the plane’—first contact with pyramid collision, entering a trigger volume, or reaching a target point?
How did you decide the acceptable tolerance for landing location (how ‘precise’ does the flight need to be for players)?
Did you consider letting players influence landing (steering, timing, camera) or is it intentionally non-steerable? Why?

open_questions.topic: Immediate A-press out of cannon causes a bug
open_questions.context: Kaze discovers pressing A on the first frame after being shot from the cannon triggers a bug; he’s unsure whether it’s vanilla Mario 64 behavior or introduced by the hack.
questions: What exactly happens in the bug (state corruption, wrong velocity, stuck animation, crash)?
Did you confirm whether this exists in vanilla SM64 on hardware, or only in R2YI?
What mitigation will ship: input buffering delay, state guard, or redesigning the cannon exit state machine?

open_questions.context: Targets can be broken by Mario’s face, but Kaze notes they still need an animation.
questions: What visual language do you want for ‘paper target breaks’—tear, fold, pop, confetti, crumple?
Who on the team owns that animation (Zeina vs. someone else), and what does the asset pipeline look like for it?
Will the animation be purely cosmetic, or tied to collision/iframes/score feedback?

open_questions.context: Kaze says the slingshot still needs to actually sling Mario; he’s currently focused on rubber-band animation timing and export correctness.
questions: What is the intended gameplay for the slingshot: fixed launch strength, chargeable, or timing-based?
How will you synchronize the animation (rubber band snap) with the moment Mario receives velocity—on a specific frame like the plane’s 7-frame timing?
Do you anticipate any N64 performance/animation update constraints when multiple animated interactables exist in the same area?

open_questions.topic: Tooling limitation: Fast64 midmap levels and flicker strategy
open_questions.context: Kaze says Fast64 supports only two midmap levels; more would require hand-written display lists, which he avoids for iteration speed. Flicker remains in some areas and seems not easily fixable with current tools.
questions: What’s the threshold where flicker becomes unacceptable and forces a workflow change (hand-authored display lists, texture redesign, or engine-side changes)?
Have you coordinated with Fast64 maintainers or considered contributing a midmap-level feature to unblock this?
Which specific demo areas are most affected, and what player-facing compromises are acceptable (lower-res textures, different materials, reduced detail)?
